page.title: 09LOCAL HISTORY (1)
page.content: The Anglo-Saxon{origin}of "Over" means "bank of the river".Land used to be owned by Ramsey Abbey and Chatteris Nunnery.Roman remains were found at Coldharbour Farm at the Willingham edge of the parish.The Ouse used to be the means of communication and boats came up to the church site until the fens were drained by Vermuyden.Dutch {houses}were built in the village-two are still inhabited(12 Fen End & 13 High St.).The old Court House,15 West St. is made of wattle and daub with overhanging upper storey and is still occupied.In Elizabethan times, Over was one of the largest villages in the county, having a market place opposite the church and an old Guild Hall replaced by a new Town Hall in 1849 through the Over Town Lands Trust.The Church school of 1843-1934 is now the church hall and play group.
